hook.text: A coup takes hours. A small group seizes the palace, the broadcast tower, and the army â€” and a government falls.

buildup.text: Coups are sudden, illegal seizures of power, usually by the military or a faction within the government.

discovery.text: Africa experienced over 200 coups since 1950. Latin America saw dozens. Coups are the most common path to power change.

twist.text: Some coups restore democracy. Portugal's 1974 coup ended dictatorship and led to free elections.

climax.text: Coups are declining globally. International pressure and economic integration raise the costs of seizing power.

punchline.text: Coups are quick and dirty. They change leaders but rarely change systems.

quiz.question: Which continent has experienced the most coups since 1950?
